"[428-someone drawing slowly near along the road] And [he]428-someone drawing slowly near along the road gave it , as [he]428-someone drawing slowly near along the road spoke , a wrench that made [me]0-i cry out . " [Sir]2853-sir , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " it is for [yourself]2853-sir [I]0-i mean . [The captain]234-the captain is not what [he]234-the captain used to be . [He]234-the captain sits with a drawn cutlass . [Another gentleman]2955-another gentleman "[0-i] " Come , now , [march]2956-march , "[428-someone drawing slowly near along the road] interrupted [he]428-someone drawing slowly near along the road ; and [I]0-i never heard a voice so cruel , and cold , and ugly as [that blind man]433-that blind man 's . It cowed [me]0-i more than the pain , and [I]0-i began to obey [him]428-someone drawing slowly near along the road at once , walking straight in at the door and towards [the parlour]216-the parlour , where [[our]435-our sick old buccaneer]436-our sick old buccaneer was sitting , dazed with rum . [The blind man]432-the blind man clung close to [me]0-i , holding [me]0-i in one iron fist and leaning almost more of [his]432-the blind man weight on [me]0-i than [I]0-i could carry . " Lead [me]432-the blind man straight up to [him]432-the blind man , and when [I]432-the blind man 'm in view , cry out , ' Here 's [a friend]2957-a friend for [you]438-the blind beggar , [Bill]69-bill . ' If [you]438-the blind beggar do n't , [I]432-the blind man 'll do this , "[432-the blind man] and with that [he]432-the blind man gave [me]0-i a twitch that [I]0-i thought would have made [me]0-i faint . Between this and that , [I]0-i was so utterly terrified of [the blind beggar]438-the blind beggar that [I]0-i forgot [my]0-i terror of [the captain]234-the captain , and as [I]0-i opened the parlour door , cried out the words [he]432-the blind man had ordered in a trembling voice . [The poor captain]440-the poor captain raised [his]440-the poor captain eyes , and at one look the rum went out of [him]440-the poor captain and left [him]440-the poor captain staring sober . The expression of [his]440-the poor captain face was not so much of terror as of mortal sickness . [He]440-the poor captain made a movement to rise , but [I]0-i do not believe [he]440-the poor captain had enough force left in [his]440-the poor captain body . " Now , [Bill]69-bill , sit where [you]69-bill are , "[441-the beggar] said [the beggar]441-the beggar . " If [I]441-the beggar ca n't see , [I]441-the beggar can hear a finger stirring . Business is business . Hold out [your]69-bill left hand . [Boy]2934-boy , take [his]234-the captain left hand by the wrist and bring it near to [my]441-the beggar right . "[441-the beggar] [We]442-we both obeyed [him]441-the beggar to the letter , and [I]0-i saw [him]441-the beggar pass something from the hollow of the hand that held [his]441-the beggar stick into the palm of [the captain]234-the captain 's , which closed upon it instantly . " And now that 's done , "[432-the blind man] said [the blind man]432-the blind man ; and at the words [he]441-the beggar suddenly left hold of [me]0-i , and with incredible accuracy and nimbleness , skipped out of [the parlour]216-the parlour and into [the road]220-the road , where , as [I]0-i still stood motionless , [I]0-i could hear [his]441-the beggar stick go tap - tap - tapping into the distance . It was some time before either [I]0-i or [the captain]234-the captain seemed to gather [our]442-we senses , but at length , and about at the same moment , [I]0-i released [his]441-the beggar wrist , which [I]0-i was still holding , and [he]441-the beggar drew in [his]441-the beggar hand and looked sharply into the palm . " Ten o'clock ! "[441-the beggar] [he]441-the beggar cried . " Six hours . [We]442-we 'll do them yet , "[441-the beggar] and [he]441-the beggar sprang to [his]441-the beggar feet . Even as [he]441-the beggar did so , [he]441-the beggar reeled , put [his]441-the beggar hand to [his]441-the beggar throat , stood swaying for a moment , and then , with a peculiar sound , fell from [his]441-the beggar whole height face foremost to the floor . [I]0-i ran to [him]441-the beggar at once , calling to [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother . But haste was all in vain . [The captain]234-the captain had been struck dead by thundering apoplexy . It is a curious thing to understand , for [I]0-i had certainly never liked [the man]2888-the man , though of late [I]0-i had begun to pity [him]2888-the man , but as soon as [I]0-i saw that [he]2888-the man was dead , [I]0-i burst into a flood of tears . It was the second death [I]0-i had known , and the sorrow of [the first]451-the first was still fresh in [my]0-i heart .

4

The Sea - chest

[I]0-i LOST no time , of course , in telling [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother all that [I]0-i knew , and perhaps should have told [her]274-my mother long before , and [we]453-we saw [ourselves]453-we at once in a difficult and dangerous position . Some of [the man]2888-the man 's money if [he]2888-the man had any was certainly due to [us]453-we , but it was not likely that [[[our]453-we captain]455-our captain 's shipmates]456-our captain 's shipmates , above all the two specimens seen by [me]0-i , [Black Dog]67-black dog and [the blind beggar]438-the blind beggar , would be inclined to give up [their]456-our captain 's shipmates booty in payment of [the dead man]2836-the dead man 's debts . [The captain]234-the captain 's order to mount at once and ride for [Doctor Livesey]71-doctor livesey would have left [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother alone and unprotected , which was not to be thought of . Indeed , it seemed impossible for either of [us]453-we to remain much longer in [the house]228-the house ; the fall of coals in the kitchen grate , the very ticking of the clock , filled [us]453-we with alarms . [The neighbourhood]462-the neighbourhood , to [our]453-we ears , seemed haunted by approaching footsteps ; and what between the dead body of [the captain on the parlour floor]463-the captain on the parlour floor and the thought of [that detestable blind beggar hovering near at hand and ready to return]464-that detestable blind beggar hovering near at hand and ready to return , there were moments when , as the saying goes , [I]0-i jumped in [my]0-i skin for terror . Something must speedily be resolved upon , and it occurred to [us]453-we at last to go forth together and seek help in [the neighbouring hamlet]465-the neighbouring hamlet . No sooner said than done . Bare - headed as [we]453-we were , [we]453-we ran out at once in the gathering evening and the frosty fog . [The hamlet]276-the hamlet lay not many hundred yards away , though out of view , on [the other side of [the next cove]468-the next cove]467-the other side of the next cove ; and what greatly encouraged [me]0-i , it was in an opposite direction from that whence [the blind man]432-the blind man had made [his]432-the blind man appearance and whither [he]432-the blind man had presumably returned . [We]453-we were not many minutes on [the road]220-the road , though [we]453-we sometimes stopped to lay hold of [each other]471-each other and hearken . But there was no unusual sound nothing but the low wash of the ripple and the croaking of the inmates of the wood . It was already candle - light when [we]453-we reached [the hamlet]276-the hamlet , and [I]0-i shall never forget how much [I]0-i was cheered to see the yellow shine in doors and windows ; but that , as it proved , was the best of the help [we]453-we were likely to get in [that quarter]473-that quarter . For [you]474-you would have thought [men]475-men would have been ashamed of [themselves]475-men [no soul]476-no soul would consent to return with [us]453-we to [the Admiral Benbow]62-the admiral benbow . The more [we]453-we told of [our]453-we troubles , the more [man]2910-man , [woman]478-woman , and [child]479-child [they]475-men clung to the shelter of [[their]475-men houses]480-their houses . The name of [Captain Flint]74-flint , though it was strange to [me]0-i , was well enough known to [some there]481-some there and carried a great weight of terror . [Some of the men who had been to field - work on [the far side of [the Admiral Benbow]62-the admiral benbow]483-the far side of the admiral benbow]482-some of the men who had been to field - work on the far side of the admiral benbow remembered , besides , to have seen [several strangers]484-several strangers on [the road]220-the road , and taking [them]484-several strangers to be [smugglers]486-smugglers , to have bolted away ; and [one at least]487-one at least had seen [a little lugger in what [we]453-we called [Kitt 's Hole]7-kitt 's hole]488-a little lugger in what we called kitt 's hole . For that matter , [anyone who was [a comrade of [the captain]234-the captain 's]490-a comrade of the captain 's]489-anyone who was a comrade of the captain 's was enough to frighten [them]484-several strangers to death . And the short and the long of the matter was , that while [we]453-we could get [several who were willing enough to ride to [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey 's]492-several who were willing enough to ride to dr. livesey 's , which lay in another direction , [not one]493-not one would help [us]453-we to defend [the inn]193-the inn . [They]492-several who were willing enough to ride to dr. livesey 's say cowardice is infectious ; but then argument is , on the other hand , a great emboldener ; and so when [each]495-each had said [his]495-each say , [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother made [them]492-several who were willing enough to ride to dr. livesey 's a speech . [She]274-my mother would not , [she]274-my mother declared , lose money that belonged to [[her]274-my mother fatherless boy]497-her fatherless boy ; " If [none of the rest of [you]2960-you]2959-none of the rest of you dare , "[274-my mother] [she]274-my mother said , " [Jim]70-jim and [I]274-my mother dare . Back [we]453-we will go , the way [we]453-we came , and small thanks to [[you]2960-you big , hulking , [chicken - hearted men]2962-chicken - hearted men]2961-you big , hulking , chicken - hearted men . [We]453-we 'll have that chest open , if [we]453-we die for it . And [I]274-my mother 'll thank [you]2960-you for that bag , [Mrs. Crossley]78-mrs. crossley , to bring back [our]453-we lawful money in . "[274-my mother] Of course [I]0-i said [I]0-i would go with [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother , and of course [they]499-they all cried out at [our]500-we foolhardiness , but even then [not a man]501-not a man would go along with [us]500-we . All [they]499-they would do was to give [me]0-i a loaded pistol lest [we]500-we were attacked , and to promise to have horses ready saddled in case [we]500-we were pursued on [our]500-we return , while [one lad]502-one lad was to ride forward to [the doctor]289-the doctor 's in search of armed assistance . [My]0-i heart was beating finely when [we]500-we two set forth in the cold night upon this dangerous venture . A full moon was beginning to rise and peered redly through the upper edges of the fog , and this increased [our]500-we haste , for it was plain , before [we]500-we came forth again , that all would be as bright as day , and [our]500-we departure exposed to the eyes of [any watchers]504-any watchers . [We]500-we slipped along the hedges , noiseless and swift , nor did [we]500-we see or hear anything to increase [our]500-we terrors , till , to [our]500-we relief , the door of [the Admiral Benbow]62-the admiral benbow had closed behind [us]500-we . [I]0-i slipped the bolt at once , and [we]500-we stood and panted for a moment in the dark , alone in [the house]228-the house with [the dead captain]506-the dead captain 's body . Then [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother got a candle in the bar , and holding [each other]471-each other 's hands , [we]500-we advanced into [the parlour]216-the parlour . [He]506-the dead captain lay as [we]500-we had left [him]506-the dead captain , on [his]506-the dead captain back , with [his]506-the dead captain eyes open and one arm stretched out . " Draw down the blind , [Jim]70-jim , "[274-my mother] whispered [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother ; " [they]2963-they might come and watch outside . And now , "[274-my mother] said [she]274-my mother when [I]0-i had done so , " [we]500-we have to get the key off THAT ; and who 's to touch it , [I]274-my mother should like to know ! "[274-my mother] and [she]274-my mother gave a kind of sob as [she]274-my mother said the words . [I]0-i went down on [my]0-i knees at once . On the floor close to [his]506-the dead captain hand there was a little round of paper , blackened on the one side . [I]0-i could not doubt that this was the BLACK SPOT ; and taking it up , [I]0-i found written on the other side , in a very good , clear hand , this short message : " [You]506-the dead captain have till ten tonight . "[0-i] " [He]506-the dead captain had till ten , [Mother]314-mother , "[0-i] said [I]0-i ; and just as [I]0-i said it , [our]511-we old clock began striking . This sudden noise startled [us]511-we shockingly ; but the news was good , for it was only six . " Now , [Jim]70-jim , "[274-my mother] [she]274-my mother said , " that key . "[274-my mother] [I]0-i felt in [his]506-the dead captain pockets , one after another . A few small coins , a thimble , and some thread and big needles , a piece of pigtail tobacco bitten away at the end , [his]506-the dead captain gully with the crooked handle , a pocket compass , and a tinder box were all that they contained , and [I]0-i began to despair . " Perhaps it 's round [his]506-the dead captain neck , "[274-my mother] suggested [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother . Overcoming a strong repugnance , [I]0-i tore open [his]506-the dead captain shirt at the neck , and there , sure enough , hanging to a bit of tarry string , which [I]0-i cut with [his]506-the dead captain own gully , [we]511-we found the key . At this triumph [we]511-we were filled with hope and hurried [upstairs]315-upstairs without delay to [the little room where [he]506-the dead captain had slept so long and where [his]506-the dead captain box had stood since the day of [his]506-the dead captain arrival]514-the little room where he had slept so long and where his box had stood since the day of his arrival . It was like [any other seaman]515-any other seaman 's chest on the outside , the initial " B "[274-my mother] burned on the top of it with a hot iron , and the corners somewhat smashed and broken as by long , rough usage . " Give [me]274-my mother the key , "[274-my mother] said [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother ; and though the lock was very stiff , [she]274-my mother had turned it and thrown back the lid in a twinkling . A strong smell of tobacco and tar rose from the interior , but nothing was to be seen on the top except a suit of very good clothes , carefully brushed and folded . They had never been worn , [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother said . Under that , [the miscellany]518-the miscellany began a quadrant , a tin canikin , several sticks of tobacco , two brace of very handsome pistols , a piece of bar silver , an old [Spanish watch and some other trinkets of little value and mostly of foreign make , a pair of compasses mounted with brass , and five or six curious West Indian shells]519-spanish watch and some other trinkets of little value and mostly of foreign make , a pair of compasses mounted with brass , and five or six curious west indian shells . [I]0-i have often wondered since why [he]506-the dead captain should have carried about these shells with [him]506-the dead captain in [his]506-the dead captain wandering , guilty , and hunted life . In the meantime , [we]511-we had found nothing of any value but the silver and the trinkets , and neither of these were in [our]511-we way . Underneath there was an old boat - cloak , whitened with sea - salt on many a harbour - bar . [[My]0-i mother]274-my mother pulled it up with impatience , and there lay before [us]511-we , the last things in the chest , a bundle tied up in oilcloth , and looking like papers , and a canvas bag that gave forth , at a touch , the jingle of gold . " [I]274-my mother 'll show [these rogues]2965-these rogues that [I]274-my mother 'm [an honest woman]2966-an honest woman , "[274-my mother] said [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother . " [I]274-my mother 'll have [my]274-my mother dues , and not a farthing over . Hold [Mrs. Crossley]78-mrs. crossley 's bag . "[274-my mother] And [she]274-my mother began to count over the amount of [the captain]234-the captain 's score from [the sailor]523-the sailor 's bag into the one that [I]0-i was holding . It was a long , difficult business , for the coins were of all countries and sizes doubloons , and louis d'ors , and guineas , and pieces of eight , and [I]0-i know not what besides , all shaken together at random . The guineas , too , were about the scarcest , and it was with these only that [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother knew how to make [her]274-my mother count . When [we]511-we were about half - way through , [I]0-i suddenly put [my]0-i hand upon [her]274-my mother arm , for [I]0-i had heard in the silent frosty air a sound that brought [my]0-i heart into [my]0-i mouth the tap - tapping of [the blind man]432-the blind man 's stick upon [the frozen road]526-the frozen road . It drew nearer and nearer , while [we]511-we sat holding [our]511-we breath . Then it struck sharp on [the inn]193-the inn door , and then [we]511-we could hear the handle being turned and the bolt rattling as the wretched being tried to enter ; and then there was a long time of silence both within and without . At last the tapping recommenced , and , to [our]511-we indescribable joy and gratitude , died slowly away again until it ceased to be heard . " [Mother]314-mother , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " take the whole and let 's be going , "[0-i] for [I]0-i was sure the bolted door must have seemed suspicious and would bring the whole hornet 's nest about [our]511-we ears , though how thankful [I]0-i was that [I]0-i had bolted [it]528-it , [none]529-none could tell who had never met [that terrible blind man]530-that terrible blind man . But [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother , frightened as [she]274-my mother was , would not consent to take a fraction more than was due to [her]274-my mother and was obstinately unwilling to be content with less . It was not yet seven , [she]274-my mother said , by a long way ; [she]274-my mother knew [her]274-my mother rights and [she]274-my mother would have them ; and [she]274-my mother was still arguing with [me]0-i when a little low whistle sounded a good way off upon [the hill]365-the hill . That was enough , and more than enough , for [both of [us]511-we]533-both of us . " [I]274-my mother 'll take what [I]274-my mother have , "[274-my mother] [she]274-my mother said , jumping to [her]274-my mother feet . " And [I]0-i 'll take this to square the count , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , picking up the oilskin packet . Next moment [we]511-we were both groping [downstairs]373-downstairs , leaving the candle by the empty chest ; and the next [we]511-we had opened the door and were in full retreat . [We]511-we had not started a moment too soon . The fog was rapidly dispersing ; already the moon shone quite clear on the high ground on either side ; and it was only in the exact bottom of [the dell]535-the dell and round the tavern door that a thin veil still hung unbroken to conceal the first steps of [our]511-we escape . Far less than half - way to [the hamlet]276-the hamlet , very little beyond [the bottom of [the hill]365-the hill]537-the bottom of the hill , [we]511-we must come forth into the moonlight . Nor was this all , for the sound of several footsteps running came already to [our]511-we ears , and as [we]511-we looked back in [their]539-their direction , a light tossing to and fro and still rapidly advancing showed that [one of [the newcomers]541-the newcomers]540-one of the newcomers carried a lantern . " [[My]274-my mother dear]2968-my dear , "[274-my mother] said [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother suddenly , " take the money and run on . [I]274-my mother am going to faint . "[274-my mother] This was certainly the end for both of [us]511-we , [I]0-i thought . How [I]0-i cursed the cowardice of [the neighbours]239-the neighbours ; how [I]0-i blamed [[my]0-i poor mother]544-my poor mother for [her]544-my poor mother honesty and [her]544-my poor mother greed , for [her]544-my poor mother past foolhardiness and present weakness ! [We]511-we were just at [the little bridge]545-the little bridge , by good fortune ; and [I]0-i helped [her]544-my poor mother , tottering as [she]544-my poor mother was , to the edge of [the bank]546-the bank , where , sure enough , [she]544-my poor mother gave a sigh and fell on [my]0-i shoulder . [I]0-i do not know how [I]0-i found the strength to do it at all , and [I]0-i am afraid it was roughly done , but [I]0-i managed to drag [her]544-my poor mother down [the bank]546-the bank and a little way under the arch . Farther [I]0-i could not move [her]544-my poor mother , for [the bridge]548-the bridge was too low to let [me]0-i do more than crawl below [it]548-the bridge . So there [we]511-we had to stay [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother almost entirely exposed and both of [us]511-we within earshot of [the inn]193-the inn .

5

The Last of [the Blind Man]432-the blind man

[MY]0-i curiosity , in a sense , was stronger than [my]0-i fear , for [I]0-i could not remain where [I]0-i was , but crept back to [the bank]546-the bank again , whence , sheltering [my]0-i head behind a bush of broom , [I]0-i might command [the road before [our]511-we door]553-the road before our door . [I]0-i was scarcely in position ere [[my]0-i enemies]554-my enemies began to arrive , seven or eight of [them]554-my enemies , running hard , [their]554-my enemies feet beating out of time along [the road]220-the road and [the man with the lantern some paces in front]556-the man with the lantern some paces in front . [Three men]557-three men ran together , hand in hand ; and [I]0-i made out , even through the mist , that [the middle man of this trio]558-the middle man of this trio was [the blind beggar]438-the blind beggar . The next moment [his]438-the blind beggar voice showed [me]0-i that [I]0-i was right . " Down with the door ! "[438-the blind beggar] [he]438-the blind beggar cried . " Aye , aye , [sir]2853-sir ! "[438-the blind beggar] answered [two or three]560-two or three ; and a rush was made upon [the Admiral Benbow]62-the admiral benbow , [the lantern - bearer]561-the lantern - bearer following ; and then [I]0-i could see [them]557-three men pause , and hear speeches passed in a lower key , as if [they]557-three men were surprised to find the door open . But the pause was brief , for [the blind man]432-the blind man again issued [his]432-the blind man commands . [His]432-the blind man voice sounded louder and higher , as if [he]432-the blind man were afire with eagerness and rage . " In , in , in ! "[432-the blind man] [he]432-the blind man shouted , and cursed [them]557-three men for [their]557-three men delay . [Four or five of [them]557-three men]563-four or five of them obeyed at once , two remaining on [the road]220-the road with [the formidable beggar]565-the formidable beggar . There was a pause , then a cry of surprise , and then a voice shouting from [the house]228-the house , " [Bill]69-bill 's dead . "[432-the blind man] But [the blind man]432-the blind man swore at [them]557-three men again for [their]557-three men delay . " Search [him]69-bill , [some of [you]557-three men shirking lubbers]2970-some of you shirking lubbers , and the rest of [you]557-three men aloft and get the chest , "[432-the blind man] [he]432-the blind man cried . [I]0-i could hear [their]557-three men feet rattling up [[our]568-our old stairs]569-our old stairs , so that [the house]228-the house must have shook with it . Promptly afterwards , fresh sounds of astonishment arose ; the window of [[the captain]234-the captain 's room]572-the captain 's room was thrown open with a slam and a jingle of broken glass , and [a man]318-a man leaned out into the moonlight , head and shoulders , and addressed [the blind beggar on [the road]220-the road below [him]318-a man]574-the blind beggar on the road below him . " [Pew]79-pew , "[318-a man] [he]318-a man cried , " [they]557-three men 've been before [us]568-our . [Someone]2971-someone 's turned the chest out alow and aloft . "[318-a man] " Is it there ? "[79-pew] roared [Pew]79-pew . " The money 's there . "[79-pew] [The blind man]432-the blind man cursed the money . " [Flint]74-flint 's fist , [I]432-the blind man mean , "[432-the blind man] [he]432-the blind man cried . " [We]568-our do n't see it here nohow , "[2888-the man] returned [the man]2888-the man . " Here , [you]79-pew below there , is it on [Bill]69-bill ? "[432-the blind man] cried [the blind man]432-the blind man again . At that [another fellow , probably [him]579-another fellow , probably him who had remained below to search the captain 's body who had remained below to search [the captain]234-the captain 's body]579-another fellow , probably him who had remained below to search the captain 's body , came to the door of [the inn]193-the inn . " [Bill]69-bill 's been overhauled a'ready , "[579-another fellow , probably him who had remained below to search the captain 's body] said [he]579-another fellow , probably him who had remained below to search the captain 's body ; " nothin' left . "[579-another fellow , probably him who had remained below to search the captain 's body] " It 's [these people of [the inn]193-the inn]2972-these people of the inn it 's [that boy]2974-that boy . [I]432-the blind man wish [I]432-the blind man had put [his]2974-that boy eyes out ! "[432-the blind man] cried [the blind man]432-the blind man , [Pew]79-pew . " There were no time ago [they]2972-these people of the inn had the door bolted when [I]579-another fellow , probably him who had remained below to search the captain 's body tried it . Scatter , [lads]2975-lads , and find 'em . "[579-another fellow , probably him who had remained below to search the captain 's body] " Sure enough , [they]2972-these people of the inn left [their]2972-these people of the inn glim here , "[583-the fellow from the window] said [the fellow from the window]583-the fellow from the window . " Scatter and find ['em]2976-'em ! Rout [the house]228-the house out ! "[79-pew] reiterated [Pew]79-pew , striking with [his]79-pew stick upon [the road]220-the road . Then there followed a great to - do through all [[our]585-we old inn]586-our old inn , heavy feet pounding to and fro , furniture thrown over , doors kicked in , until the very rocks re - echoed and [the men]587-the men came out again , one after another , on [the road]220-the road and declared that [we]585-we were nowhere to be found . And just the same whistle that had alarmed [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother and [myself]0-i over [the dead captain]506-the dead captain 's money was once more clearly audible through the night , but this time twice repeated . [I]0-i had thought it to be [the blind man]432-the blind man 's trumpet , so to speak , summoning [[his]432-the blind man crew]592-his crew to the assault , but [I]0-i now found that it was a signal from [the hillside]593-the hillside towards [the hamlet]276-the hamlet , and from its effect upon [the buccaneers]595-the buccaneers , a signal to warn [them]595-the buccaneers of approaching danger . " There 's [Dirk]80-dirk again , "[596-one] said [one]596-one . " Twice ! [We]585-we 'll have to budge , [mates]2978-mates . "[596-one] " Budge , [you]2979-you skulk ! "[79-pew] cried [Pew]79-pew . " [Dirk]80-dirk was [a fool]2916-a fool and [a coward]2981-a coward from the first [you]2979-you would n't mind [him]80-dirk . [They]595-the buccaneers must be close by ; [they]595-the buccaneers ca n't be far ; [you]2979-you have [your]2979-you hands on it . Scatter and look for [them]595-the buccaneers , dogs ! Oh , shiver [my]79-pew soul , "[79-pew] [he]79-pew cried , " if [I]79-pew had eyes ! "[79-pew] This appeal seemed to produce some effect , for [two of [the fellows]598-the fellows]597-two of the fellows began to look here and there among the lumber , but half - heartedly , [I]0-i thought , and with half an eye to [their]597-two of the fellows own danger all the time , while [the rest]599-the rest stood irresolute on [the road]220-the road . " [You]2979-you have [your]2979-you hands on [thousands]2982-thousands , [[you]2979-you fools]2983-you fools , and [you]2979-you hang a leg ! [You]2979-you 'd be as rich as [kings]2984-kings if [you]2979-you could find it , and [you]2979-you know it 's here , and [you]2979-you stand there skulking . There was n't [one of [you]2979-you]2985-one of you dared face [Bill]69-bill , and [I]596-one did it [a blind man]2986-a blind man ! And [I]596-one 'm to lose [my]596-one chance for [you]2979-you ! [I]596-one 'm to be [a poor , crawling beggar]2987-a poor , crawling beggar , sponging for rum , when [I]596-one might be rolling in [a coach]2988-a coach ! If [you]2979-you had the pluck of a weevil in a biscuit [you]2979-you would catch [them]2989-them still . "[596-one] " Hang it , [Pew]79-pew , [we]2990-we 've got [the doubloons]2991-the doubloons ! "[596-one] grumbled [one]596-one . " [They]2991-the doubloons might have hid the blessed thing , "[602-another] said [another]602-another . " Take [the Georges]2992-the georges , [Pew]79-pew , and do n't stand here squalling . "[602-another] Squalling was the word for it ; [Pew]79-pew 's anger rose so high at these objections till at last , [his]79-pew passion completely taking the upper hand , [he]79-pew struck at [them]603-them right and left in [his]79-pew blindness and [his]79-pew stick sounded heavily on more than one . [These]604-these , in [their]604-these turn , cursed back at [the blind miscreant]605-the blind miscreant , threatened [him]79-pew in horrid terms , and tried in vain to catch the stick and wrest it from [his]79-pew grasp . This quarrel was the saving of [us]606-us , for while it was still raging , another sound came from the top of [the hill]365-the hill on [the side of [the hamlet]276-the hamlet]608-the side of the hamlet the tramp of horses galloping . Almost at the same time a pistol - shot , flash and report , came from the hedge side . And that was plainly the last signal of danger , for [the buccaneers]595-the buccaneers turned at once and ran , separating in every direction , one seaward along [the cove]214-the cove , one slant across [the hill]365-the hill , and so on , so that in half a minute not a sign of [them]595-the buccaneers remained but [Pew]79-pew . [Him]79-pew [they]595-the buccaneers had deserted , whether in sheer panic or out of revenge for [his]79-pew ill words and blows [I]0-i know not ; but there [he]79-pew remained behind , tapping up and down [the road]220-the road in a frenzy , and groping and calling for [[his]79-pew comrades]614-his comrades . Finally [he]79-pew took a wrong turn and ran a few steps past [me]0-i , towards [the hamlet]276-the hamlet , crying , " [Johnny]73-jack , [Black Dog]2993-black dog , [Dirk]80-dirk , "[79-pew] and other names , " [you]0-i wo n't leave [old Pew]79-pew , mates not [old Pew]79-pew ! "[79-pew] Just then the noise of [horses]616-horses topped the rise , and [four or five riders]617-four or five riders came in sight in the moonlight and swept at full gallop down [the slope]618-the slope . At this [Pew]79-pew saw [his]79-pew error , turned with a scream , and ran straight for the ditch , into which [he]79-pew rolled . But [he]79-pew was on [his]79-pew feet again in a second and made another dash , now utterly bewildered , right under the nearest of the coming horses . [The rider]619-the rider tried to save [him]79-pew , but in vain . Down went [Pew]79-pew with a cry that rang high into the night ; and the four hoofs trampled and spurned [him]79-pew and passed by . [He]79-pew fell on [his]79-pew side , then gently collapsed upon [his]79-pew face and moved no more . [I]0-i leaped to [my]0-i feet and hailed [the riders]620-the riders . [They]620-the riders were pulling up , at any rate , horrified at the accident ; and [I]0-i soon saw what [they]620-the riders were . One , tailing out behind [the rest]599-the rest , was [a lad that had gone from [the hamlet]276-the hamlet to [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey 's]622-a lad that had gone from the hamlet to dr. livesey 's ; [the rest]599-the rest were [revenue officers , whom [he]79-pew had met by the way , and with whom [he]79-pew had had the intelligence to return at once]625-revenue officers , whom he had met by the way , and with whom he had had the intelligence to return at once . Some news of [the lugger in [[Kitt]81-kitt 's Hole]7-kitt 's hole]626-the lugger in kitt 's hole had found its way to [Supervisor Dance]82-supervisor dance and set [him]82-supervisor dance forth that night in [our]627-our direction , and to that circumstance [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother and [I]0-i owed [our]627-our preservation from death . [Pew]79-pew was dead , stone dead . As for [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother , when [we]627-our had carried [her]274-my mother up to [the hamlet]276-the hamlet , a little cold water and salts and that soon brought [her]274-my mother back again , and [she]274-my mother was none the worse for [her]274-my mother terror , though [she]274-my mother still continued to deplore the balance of the money . In the meantime [the supervisor]631-the supervisor rode on , as fast as [he]631-the supervisor could , to [[Kitt]81-kitt 's Hole]632-kitt 's hole ; but [[his]631-the supervisor men]633-his men had to dismount and grope down the dingle , leading , and sometimes supporting , [their]633-his men horses , and in continual fear of ambushes ; so it was no great matter for surprise that when [they]633-his men got down to [the Hole]634-the hole [the lugger]635-the lugger was already under way , though still close in . [He]631-the supervisor hailed [her]274-my mother . [A voice]636-a voice replied , telling [him]631-the supervisor to keep out of the moonlight or [he]631-the supervisor would get some lead in [him]631-the supervisor , and at the same time a bullet whistled close by [his]631-the supervisor arm . Soon after , [the lugger]635-the lugger doubled the point and disappeared . [Mr. Dance]83-mr. dance stood there , as [he]83-mr. dance said , " like a fish out of water , "[83-mr. dance] and all [he]83-mr. dance could do was to dispatch [a man to [B]84-b]638-a man to b to warn [the cutter]639-the cutter . " And that , "[83-mr. dance] said [he]83-mr. dance , " is just about as good as nothing . [They]639-the cutter 've got off clean , and there 's an end . Only , "[83-mr. dance] [he]83-mr. dance added , " [I]83-mr. dance 'm glad [I]83-mr. dance trod on [[Master Pew]79-pew 's corns]2994-master pew 's corns , "[83-mr. dance] for by this time [he]83-mr. dance had heard [my]0-i story . [I]0-i went back with [him]83-mr. dance to [the Admiral Benbow]2947-the admiral benbow , and [you]641-you can not imagine [a house]642-a house in such a state of smash ; the very clock had been thrown down by [these fellows]643-these fellows in [their]643-these fellows furious hunt after [[my]0-i mother]274-my mother and [myself]0-i ; and though nothing had actually been taken away except [the captain]234-the captain 's money - bag and a little silver from the till , [I]0-i could see at once that [we]646-we were ruined . [Mr. Dance]83-mr. dance could make nothing of the scene . " [They]643-these fellows got the money , [you]83-mr. dance say ? Well , then , [Hawkins]70-jim , what in fortune were [they]643-these fellows after ? More money , [I]83-mr. dance suppose ? "[83-mr. dance] " No , [sir]2853-sir ; not money , [I]0-i think , "[0-i] replied [I.]0-i " In fact , [sir]2853-sir , [I]0-i believe [I]0-i have the thing in [my]0-i breast pocket ; and to tell [you]2853-sir the truth , [I]0-i should like to get it put in safety . "[0-i] " To be sure , [boy]2934-boy ; quite right , "[83-mr. dance] said [he]83-mr. dance . " [I]83-mr. dance 'll take it , if [you]2934-boy like . "[83-mr. dance] " [I]0-i thought perhaps [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey "[0-i] [I]0-i began . " Perfectly right , "[83-mr. dance] [he]83-mr. dance interrupted very cheerily , " perfectly right [a gentleman]2998-a gentleman and [a magistrate]303-a magistrate . [Master Pew]79-pew 's dead , when all 's done ; not that [I]83-mr. dance regret it , but [he]79-pew 's dead , [you]2934-boy see , and [people]245-people will make it out against [an officer of [[his]79-pew Majesty]3004-his majesty 's revenue]3003-an officer of his majesty 's revenue , if make it out [they]245-people can . "[83-mr. dance] [I]0-i thanked [him]647-you heartily for the offer , and [we]648-we walked back to [the hamlet where the horses were]649-the hamlet where the horses were . By the time [I]0-i had told [mother]314-mother of [my]0-i purpose [they]651-they were all in the saddle . " [Dogger]85-dogger , "[83-mr. dance] said [Mr. Dance]83-mr. dance , " [you]647-you have a good horse ; take up [this lad]3005-this lad behind [you]647-you . "[83-mr. dance] As soon as [I]0-i was mounted , holding on to [Dogger]85-dogger 's belt , [the supervisor]631-the supervisor gave the word , and [the party]653-the party struck out at a bouncing trot on [the road]220-the road to [[Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey 's house]655-dr. livesey 's house .

6

[The Captain]234-the captain 's Papers

[WE]648-we rode hard all the way till [we]648-we drew up before [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey 's door . [The house]228-the house was all dark to the front . [Mr. Dance]83-mr. dance told [me]0-i to jump down and knock , and [Dogger]85-dogger gave [me]0-i a stirrup to descend by . The door was opened almost at once by [the maid]658-the maid . " Is [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey in ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked . No , [she]658-the maid said , [he]63-dr. livesey had come [home]659-home in the afternoon but had gone up to [the hall]660-the hall to dine and pass the evening with [the squire]661-the squire . " So there [we]3006-we go , [boys]2870-boys , "[83-mr. dance] said [Mr. Dance]83-mr. dance . This time , as the distance was short , [I]0-i did not mount , but ran with [Dogger]85-dogger 's stirrup - leather to [the lodge]662-the lodge gates and up [the long , leafless , moonlit avenue to where the white line of [the hall buildings]664-the hall buildings looked on either hand on [great old gardens]665-great old gardens]663-the long , leafless , moonlit avenue to where the white line of the hall buildings looked on either hand on great old gardens . Here [Mr. Dance]83-mr. dance dismounted , and taking [me]0-i along with [him]83-mr. dance , was admitted at a word into [the house]228-the house . [The servant]667-the servant led [us]668-us down [a matted passage]669-a matted passage and showed [us]668-us at the end into [a great library]670-a great library , all lined with bookcases and busts upon the top of [them]670-a great library , where [the squire]661-the squire and [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey sat , pipe in hand , on either side of a bright fire . [I]0-i had never seen [the squire so near at hand]672-the squire so near at hand . [He]661-the squire was [a tall man]673-a tall man , over six feet high , and broad in proportion , and [he]661-the squire had a bluff , rough - and - ready face , all roughened and reddened and lined in [his]661-the squire long travels . [His]661-the squire eyebrows were very black , and moved readily , and this gave [him]661-the squire a look of some temper , not bad , [you]674-you would say , but quick and high . " Come in , [Mr. Dance]83-mr. dance , "[661-the squire] says [he]661-the squire , very stately and condescending . [[The squire]661-the squire]661-the squire and [I]0-i were both peering over [his]289-the doctor shoulder as [he]289-the doctor opened it , for [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey had kindly motioned [me]0-i to come round from the side - table , where [I]0-i had been eating , to enjoy the sport of the search . [I]0-i could not help wondering who it was that had " got itt , "[63-dr. livesey] and what " itt "[289-the doctor] was that [he]289-the doctor got . A knife in [his]289-the doctor back as like as not . " Not much instruction there , "[63-dr. livesey] said [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey as [he]63-dr. livesey passed on . The next ten or twelve pages were filled with a curious series of entries . There was a date at one end of the line and at the other a sum of money , as in common account - books , but instead of explanatory writing , only a varying number of crosses between the two . On the 12th of June , 1745 , for instance , a sum of seventy pounds had plainly become due to [someone]2971-someone , and there was nothing but six crosses to explain the cause . In a few cases , to be sure , the name of [a place]703-a place would be added , as " Offe Caraccas , "[2971-someone] or a mere entry of latitude and longitude , as " 62o 17 ' 20 "[2971-someone] , 19o 2 ' 40 " . "[2971-someone] The record lasted over nearly twenty years , the amount of the separate entries growing larger as time went on , and at the end a grand total had been made out after five or six wrong additions , and these words appended , " [Bones]89-mr. w. bones , [his]289-the doctor pile . "[2971-someone] " [I]63-dr. livesey ca n't make head or tail of this , "[63-dr. livesey] said [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey . " The thing is as clear as noonday , "[661-the squire] cried [the squire]661-the squire . " This is the black - hearted hound 's account - book . These crosses stand for the names of ships or towns that [they]3037-they sank or plundered . The sums are [the scoundrel]3038-the scoundrel 's share , and where [he]289-the doctor feared an ambiguity , [you]0-i see [he]289-the doctor added something clearer . ' Offe Caraccas , ' now ; [you]0-i see , here was some unhappy vessel boarded off [that coast]3039-that coast . God help [the poor souls that manned [her]3041-her coral]3040-the poor souls that manned her coral long ago . "[661-the squire] " Right ! "[289-the doctor] said [the doctor]289-the doctor . "[289-the doctor] There was little else in the volume but a few bearings of places noted in the blank leaves towards the end and a table for reducing French , English , and Spanish moneys to a common value . " [Thrifty man]3043-thrifty man ! "[289-the doctor] cried [the doctor]289-the doctor . " [He]289-the doctor was n't [the one to be cheated]3044-the one to be cheated . "[289-the doctor] " And now , "[661-the squire] said [the squire]661-the squire , " for the other . "[661-the squire] The paper had been sealed in several places with a thimble by way of seal ; the very thimble , perhaps , that [I]0-i had found in [the captain]234-the captain 's pocket . [The doctor]289-the doctor opened the seals with great care , and there fell out the map of [an island]710-an island , with latitude and longitude , soundings , names of [hills and bays]711-hills and bays and [inlets]712-inlets , and every particular that would be needed to bring [a ship]713-a ship to [a safe anchorage upon [its shores]715-its shores]714-a safe anchorage upon its shores . [It]710-an island was about nine miles long and five across , shaped , [you]716-you might say , like a fat dragon standing up , and had two fine land - locked harbours , and a hill in the centre part marked " [The Spy - glass]3045-the spy - glass . "[716-you] There were several additions of a later date , but above all , three crosses of red ink two on [the north part of [the island]187-the island]717-the north part of the island , one in the southwest and beside this last , in the same red ink , and in a small , neat hand , very different from [the captain]234-the captain 's tottery characters , these words : " Bulk of treasure here . Ten feet .

The bar silver is in [the north cache]720-the north cache ; [you]716-you can find it by [the trend of [the east hummock]722-the east hummock]721-the trend of the east hummock , ten fathoms south of the black crag with the face on it .

PART TWO [The Sea - cook]732-the sea - cook

7

[I]0-i Go to [Bristol]12-bristol

IT was longer than [the squire]661-the squire imagined ere [we]734-we were ready for [the sea]250-the sea , and none of [our]734-we first plans not even [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey 's , of keeping [me]0-i beside [him]63-dr. livesey could be carried out as [we]734-we intended . [The doctor]289-the doctor had to go to [London]13-london for [a physician]737-a physician to take charge of [[his]63-dr. livesey practice]738-his practice ; [the squire]661-the squire was hard at work at [Bristol]12-bristol ; and [I]0-i lived on at [the hall]660-the hall under the charge of [old Redruth]91-redruth , [the gamekeeper]741-the gamekeeper , almost [a prisoner]742-a prisoner , but full of sea - dreams and the most charming anticipations of [strange islands]743-strange islands and adventures . [I]0-i brooded by the hour together over the map , all the details of which [I]0-i well remembered . Sitting by the fire in [[the housekeeper]744-the housekeeper 's room]745-the housekeeper 's room , [I]0-i approached [that island]746-that island in [my]0-i fancy from every possible direction ; [I]0-i explored [every acre of [its]746-that island surface]747-every acre of its surface ; [I]0-i climbed a thousand times to [that tall hill [they]749-they call [the Spy - glass]3045-the spy - glass]748-that tall hill they call the spy - glass , and from the top enjoyed the most wonderful and changing prospects . Sometimes [the isle]751-the isle was thick with savages , with whom [we]752-we fought , sometimes full of dangerous animals that hunted [us]752-we , but in all [my]0-i fancies nothing occurred to [me]0-i so strange and tragic as [our]752-we actual adventures . So the weeks passed on , till one fine day there came a letter addressed to [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey , with this addition , " To be opened , in the case of [his]63-dr. livesey absence , by [Tom Redruth]91-redruth or [young Hawkins]70-jim . "[63-dr. livesey] Obeying this order , [we]752-we found , or rather [I]0-i found for [the gamekeeper]741-the gamekeeper was a poor hand at reading anything but print the following important news : [Old Anchor Inn]14-old anchor inn , [Bristol]12-bristol , March 1 , 17

[Dear Livesey]63-dr. livesey As [I]0-i do not know whether [you]63-dr. livesey are at [the hall]660-the hall or still in [London]13-london , [I]0-i send this in double to both places .

[The ship]755-the ship is bought and fitted . [She]755-the ship lies at anchor , ready for [sea]246-sea . [You]757-you never imagined [a sweeter schooner]758-a sweeter schooner [a child]402-a child might sail [her]755-the ship two hundred tons ; name , [HISPANIOLA]16-the hispaniola .

[I]0-i got [her]755-the ship through [[my]0-i old friend]760-my old friend , [Blandly]94-blandly , who has proved [himself]94-blandly throughout the most surprising trump . [The admirable fellow]761-the admirable fellow literally slaved in [my]0-i interest , and so , [I]0-i may say , did [everyone in [Bristol]12-bristol]762-everyone in bristol , as soon as [they]762-everyone in bristol got wind of [the port]763-the port [we]764-we sailed for treasure , [I]0-i mean . " [Redruth]91-redruth , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , interrupting the letter , " [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey will not like that . [The squire]661-the squire has been talking , after all . "[0-i] " Well , who 's a better right ? "[741-the gamekeeper] growled [the gamekeeper]741-the gamekeeper . " [A pretty rum]3067-a pretty rum go if [squire]62-the admiral benbow ai n't to talk for [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey , [I]741-the gamekeeper should think . "[741-the gamekeeper] At that [I]0-i gave up all attempts at commentary and read straight on : [Blandly]94-blandly [himself]94-blandly found the HISPANIOLA , and by [the most admirable management]766-the most admirable management got [her]767-her for the merest trifle . There is [a class of men in [Bristol]12-bristol]768-a class of men in bristol monstrously prejudiced against [Blandly]94-blandly . [They]768-a class of men in bristol go the length of declaring that [this honest creature]769-this honest creature would do anything for money , that [the HISPANIOLA]16-the hispaniola belonged to [him]94-blandly , and that [he]94-blandly sold it [me]0-i absurdly high [the most transparent calumnies]770-the most transparent calumnies . [None of [them]768-a class of men in bristol]771-none of them dare , however , to deny the merits of [the ship]755-the ship .

So far there was not a hitch . [The workpeople]773-the workpeople , to be sure [riggers]774-riggers and what not were most annoyingly slow ; but time cured that . It was the crew that troubled [me]0-i .

[I]0-i wished a round score of [men]475-men in case of [natives]776-natives , [buccaneers , or the odious French]777-buccaneers , or the odious french and [I]0-i had the worry of the deuce itself to find so much as half a dozen , till the most remarkable stroke of fortune brought [me]0-i [the very man that [I]0-i required]778-the very man that i required .

[I]0-i was standing on [the dock]779-the dock , when , by the merest accident , [I]0-i fell in talk with [him]94-blandly . [I]0-i found [he]94-blandly was [an old sailor]780-an old sailor , kept [a public - house]781-a public - house , knew [all the seafaring men in [Bristol]12-bristol]782-all the seafaring men in bristol , had lost [his]94-blandly health ashore , and wanted a good berth as [cook]783-cook to get to [sea]246-sea again . [He]94-blandly had hobbled down [there]2846-there that morning , [he]94-blandly said , to get a smell of the salt .

[I]0-i was monstrously touched so would [you]786-you have been and , out of pure pity , [I]0-i engaged [him]94-blandly on the spot to be [ship 's cook]787-ship 's cook . [Long John Silver]95-silver , [he]95-silver is called , and has lost a leg ; but that [I]0-i regarded as a recommendation , since [he]95-silver lost it in [[his]95-silver country]788-his country 's service , under the immortal [Hawke]96-hawke . [He]95-silver has no pension , [Livesey]63-dr. livesey . Imagine the abominable age [we]789-we live in !

Well , [sir]2853-sir , [I]0-i thought [I]0-i had only found [a cook]791-a cook , but it was a crew [I]0-i had discovered . Between [Silver]95-silver and [myself]0-i [we]789-we got together in a few days [a company of the toughest old salts imaginable not pretty to look at]792-a company of the toughest old salts imaginable not pretty to look at , but [fellows]793-fellows , by [their]793-fellows faces , of the most indomitable spirit . [I]0-i declare [we]789-we could fight [a frigate]794-a frigate .

[Long John]95-silver even got rid of two out of the six or seven [I]0-i had already engaged . [He]95-silver showed [me]0-i in a moment that [they]795-they were just the sort of fresh - water swabs [we]789-we had to fear in an adventure of importance .

[I]0-i am in the most magnificent health and spirits , eating like a bull , sleeping like a tree , yet [I]0-i shall not enjoy a moment till [I]0-i hear [my]0-i old tarpaulins tramping round the capstan . Seaward , ho ! Hang the treasure ! It 's the glory of [the sea]250-the sea that has turned [my]0-i head . So now , [Livesey]63-dr. livesey , come post ; do not lose an hour , if [you]63-dr. livesey respect [me]0-i .

Let [young Hawkins]70-jim go at once to see [[his]70-jim mother]797-his mother , with [Redruth]91-redruth for [a guard]798-a guard ; and then both come full speed to [Bristol]12-bristol . [John Trelawney]97-john trelawney

Postscript [I]0-i did not tell [you]63-dr. livesey that Blandly , who , by the way , is to send [a consort]799-a consort after [us]789-we if [we]789-we do n't turn up by the end of August , had found [an admirable fellow for [sailing master]801-sailing master [a stiff man]802-a stiff man , which [I]0-i regret , but in all other respects a treasure]800-an admirable fellow for sailing master a stiff man , which i regret , but in all other respects a treasure . [Long John Silver]95-silver unearthed [a very competent man]803-a very competent man for [a mate]203-a mate , [a man named [Arrow]98-mr. arrow]805-a man named arrow . [I]0-i have [a boatswain who pipes , Livesey]806-a boatswain who pipes , livesey ; so things shall go man - o'-war fashion on board [the good ship]807-the good ship [HISPANIOLA]808-hispaniola .

[I]0-i forgot to tell [you]63-dr. livesey that [Silver]95-silver is [a man of substance]809-a man of substance ; [I]0-i know of [my]0-i own knowledge that [he]95-silver has [a banker]810-a banker 's account , which has never been overdrawn . [It]887-the tavern was [a bright enough little place of entertainment]888-a bright enough little place of entertainment . The sign was newly painted ; the windows had neat red curtains ; the floor was cleanly sanded . There was [a street]889-a street on each side and an open door on both , which made [the large , low room pretty clear to see in]890-the large , low room pretty clear to see in , in spite of clouds of tobacco smoke . [The customers]891-the customers were [mostly seafaring men]892-mostly seafaring men , and [they]891-the customers talked so loudly that [I]0-i hung at the door , almost afraid to enter . [His]318-a man left leg was cut off close by the hip , and under the left shoulder [he]318-a man carried a crutch , which [he]318-a man managed with wonderful dexterity , hopping about upon it like a bird . [He]318-a man was very tall and strong , with a face as big as a ham plain and pale , but intelligent and smiling . "[920-my] And [he]923-he began to laugh again , and that so heartily , that though [I]0-i did not see the joke as [he]923-he did , [I]0-i was again obliged to join [him]923-he in [his]923-he mirth . On [our]924-we little walk along [the quays]853-the quays , [he]923-he made [himself]923-he [the most interesting companion]926-the most interesting companion , telling [me]0-i about [the different ships that [we]924-we passed by]927-the different ships that we passed by , [their]927-the different ships that we passed by rig , tonnage , and nationality , explaining the work that was going forward how one was discharging , another taking in cargo , and a third making ready for [sea]246-sea and every now and then telling [me]0-i some little anecdote of [ships]2844-ships or [seamen]884-seamen or repeating a nautical phrase till [I]0-i had learned it perfectly . [I]0-i began to see that here was one of the best of [possible shipmates]931-possible shipmates . When [we]924-we got to [the inn]193-the inn , [the squire]661-the squire and [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey were seated together , finishing a quart of ale with a toast in it , before [they]934-they should go aboard [the schooner]852-the schooner on a visit of inspection . [Long John]95-silver told the story from first to last , with a great deal of spirit and the most perfect truth . " That was how it were , now , were n't it , [Hawkins]99-hawkins ? "[95-silver] [he]95-silver would say , now and again , and [I]0-i could always bear [him]95-silver entirely out . " [All hands]3111-all hands aboard by four this afternoon , "[661-the squire] shouted [the squire]661-the squire after [him]95-silver . 10

The Voyage

ALL that night [we]1024-we were in a great bustle getting things stowed in [their]1025-their place , and [boatfuls of [[the squire]661-the squire 's friends]1028-the squire 's friends]1026-boatfuls of the squire 's friends , [Mr. Blandly]94-blandly and the like , coming off to wish [him]661-the squire a good voyage and a safe return . [We]1024-we never had a night at [the Admiral Benbow]62-the admiral benbow when [I]0-i had half the work ; and [I]0-i was dog - tired when , a little before dawn , [the boatswain]1029-the boatswain sounded [his]1029-the boatswain pipe and [the crew]966-the crew began to man the capstan - bars . [I]0-i might have been twice as weary , yet [I]0-i would not have left [the deck]1031-the deck , all was so new and interesting to [me]0-i the brief commands , the shrill note of the whistle , [the men]587-the men bustling to [their]587-the men places in the glimmer of [the ship]755-the ship 's lanterns . " Now , [Barbecue]110-barbecue , tip [us]1024-we [a stave]3192-a stave , "[95-silver] cried one voice . " [The old one]3193-the old one , "[95-silver] cried another . " Aye , aye , [mates]2978-mates , "[95-silver] said [Long John]95-silver , who was standing by , with [his]95-silver crutch under [his]95-silver arm , and at once broke out in the air and words [I]0-i knew so well : " [Fifteen men on [the dead man]2836-the dead man]2835-fifteen men on the dead man 's chest "[95-silver] And then [the whole crew]1034-the whole crew bore chorus : " Yo - ho - ho , and a bottle of rum ! "[1034-the whole crew] And at the third " Ho ! "[1034-the whole crew] drove the bars before [them]1034-the whole crew with a will . Even at that exciting moment it carried [me]0-i back to [the old Admiral Benbow]1035-the old admiral benbow in a second , and [I]0-i seemed to hear the voice of [the captain piping in the chorus]1036-the captain piping in the chorus . But soon the anchor was short up ; soon it was hanging dripping at the bows ; soon the sails began to draw , and [the land]1037-the land and shipping to flit by on either side ; and before [I]0-i could lie down to snatch an hour of slumber the HISPANIOLA had begun [her]1038-her voyage to [the Isle of Treasure]18-the isle of treasure . [I]0-i am not going to relate that voyage in detail . It was fairly prosperous . [The ship]755-the ship proved to be [a good ship]1040-a good ship , [the crew]966-the crew were [capable seamen]1042-capable seamen , and [the captain]234-the captain thoroughly understood [his]234-the captain business . But before [we]1044-we came the length of [Treasure Island]1-treasure island , two or three things had happened which require to be known . [Mr. Arrow]98-mr. arrow , first of all , turned out even worse than [the captain]234-the captain had feared . [He]98-mr. arrow had no command among [the men]587-the men , and [people]245-people did what [they]245-people pleased with [him]98-mr. arrow . But that was by no means the worst of it , for after a day or two at [sea]246-sea [he]98-mr. arrow began to appear on [deck]3158-deck with hazy eye , red cheeks , stuttering tongue , and other marks of drunkenness . Time after time [he]98-mr. arrow was ordered below in disgrace . Sometimes [he]98-mr. arrow fell and cut [himself]98-mr. arrow ; sometimes [he]98-mr. arrow lay all day long in [[his]98-mr. arrow little bunk at one side of [the companion]1051-the companion]1050-his little bunk at one side of the companion ; sometimes for a day or two [he]98-mr. arrow would be almost sober and attend to [his]98-mr. arrow work at least passably . In the meantime , [we]1052-we could never make out where [he]98-mr. arrow got the drink . That was [the ship]755-the ship 's mystery . Watch [him]98-mr. arrow as [we]1052-we pleased , [we]1052-we could do nothing to solve it ; and when [we]1052-we asked [him]98-mr. arrow to [his]98-mr. arrow face , [he]98-mr. arrow would only laugh if [he]98-mr. arrow were drunk , and if [he]98-mr. arrow were sober deny solemnly that [he]98-mr. arrow ever tasted anything but water . [He]98-mr. arrow was not only useless as [an officer]1054-an officer and a bad influence amongst [the men]587-the men , but it was plain that at this rate [he]98-mr. arrow must soon kill [himself]98-mr. arrow outright , so [nobody]236-nobody was much surprised , nor very sorry , when one dark night , with a head sea , [he]98-mr. arrow disappeared entirely and was seen no more . " Overboard ! "[234-the captain] said [the captain]234-the captain . " Well , [gentlemen]979-gentlemen , that saves the trouble of putting [him]98-mr. arrow in irons . "[234-the captain] But there [we]1052-we were , without [a mate]203-a mate ; and it was necessary , of course , to advance [one of [the men]587-the men]1059-one of the men . [The boatswain]1029-the boatswain , [Job Anderson]111-anderson , was [the likeliest man aboard]1062-the likeliest man aboard , and though [he]1029-the boatswain kept [his]1029-the boatswain old title , [he]1029-the boatswain served in a way as [mate]2839-mate . [Mr. Trelawney]86-mr. trelawney had followed [the sea]250-the sea , and [his]86-mr. trelawney knowledge made [him]86-mr. trelawney very useful , for [he]86-mr. trelawney often took a watch [himself]86-mr. trelawney in easy weather . [He]1065-the coxswain was [a great confidant of [Long John Silver]95-silver]1067-a great confidant of long john silver , and so the mention of [his]1065-the coxswain name leads [me]0-i on to speak of [[our]1068-our ship 's cook]1069-our ship 's cook , [Barbecue]110-barbecue , as [the men]587-the men called [him]110-barbecue . Aboard [ship]3051-ship [he]110-barbecue carried [his]110-barbecue crutch by a lanyard round [his]110-barbecue neck , to have both hands as free as possible . It was something to see [him]110-barbecue wedge the foot of the crutch against a bulkhead , and propped against it , yielding to every movement of [the ship]755-the ship , get on with [his]110-barbecue cooking like [someone safe ashore]1073-someone safe ashore . Still more strange was it to see [him]110-barbecue in the heaviest of weather cross [the deck]1031-the deck . [He]110-barbecue had a line or two rigged up to help [him]110-barbecue across [the widest spaces Long John 's earrings]1075-the widest spaces long john 's earrings , [they]587-the men were called ; and [he]110-barbecue would hand [himself]110-barbecue from one place to another , now using the crutch , now trailing it alongside by the lanyard , as quickly as [another man]1076-another man could walk . " [He]110-barbecue had good schooling in [his]110-barbecue young days and can speak like a book when so minded ; and brave a lion 's nothing alongside of [Long John]95-silver ! [He]110-barbecue had a way of talking to each and doing [everybody]1081-everybody some particular service . [The captain]234-the captain , on [his]234-the captain part , never spoke but when [he]234-the captain was spoken to , and then sharp and short and dry , and not a word wasted . [He]234-the captain owned , when driven into a corner , that [he]234-the captain seemed to have been wrong about [the crew]966-the crew , that some of [them]966-the crew were as brisk as [he]234-the captain wanted to see and all had behaved fairly well . " A trifle more of [that man]1009-that man , "[661-the squire] [he]661-the squire would say , " and [I]661-the squire shall explode . "[661-the squire] [We]1096-we had some heavy weather , which only proved the qualities of [the HISPANIOLA]16-the hispaniola . [Every man on board]1097-every man on board seemed well content , and [they]1097-every man on board must have been hard to please if [they]1097-every man on board had been otherwise , for it is [my]0-i belief there was never [[a ship]713-a ship 's company so spoiled since [Noah]114-noah put to [sea]246-sea]1099-a ship 's company so spoiled since noah put to sea . Double grog was going on the least excuse ; there was duff on odd days , as , for instance , if [the squire]661-the squire heard it was [any man]1102-any man 's birthday , and always a barrel of apples standing broached in the waist for anyone to help [himself]661-the squire that had a fancy . " Never knew good come of it yet , "[234-the captain] [the captain]234-the captain said to [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey . " Spoil forecastle hands , make devils . That 's [my]234-the captain belief . "[234-the captain] But good did come of the apple barrel , as [you]1104-you shall hear , for if it had not been for that , [we]1096-we should have had no note of warning and might all have perished by the hand of treachery . This was how it came about . [We]1096-we had run up [the trades]1105-the trades to get the wind of [the island]187-the island [we]1096-we were after [I]0-i am not allowed to be more plain and now [we]1096-we were running down for it with a bright lookout day and night . It was about the last day of [our]1096-we outward voyage by [the largest computation]1107-the largest computation ; some time that night , or at latest before noon of the morrow , [we]1096-we should sight [the Treasure Island]1-treasure island . [We]1096-we were heading S.S.W. and had a steady breeze abeam and [a quiet sea]1108-a quiet sea . [The HISPANIOLA]16-the hispaniola rolled steadily , dipping [her]16-the hispaniola bowsprit now and then with a whiff of spray . All was drawing alow and aloft ; [everyone]1109-everyone was in the bravest spirits because [we]1096-we were now so near an end of the first part of [our]1096-we adventure . Now , just after sundown , when all [my]0-i work was over and [I]0-i was on [my]0-i way to [[my]0-i berth]1110-my berth , it occurred to [me]0-i that [I]0-i should like an apple . [I]0-i ran on [deck]3158-deck . The watch was all forward looking out for [the island]187-the island . [The man at the helm]1113-the man at the helm was watching the luff of the sail and whistling away gently to [himself]1113-the man at the helm , and that was the only sound excepting the swish of [the sea]250-the sea against the bows and around the sides of [the ship]755-the ship . In [I]0-i got bodily into the apple barrel , and found there was scarce an apple left ; but sitting down there in the dark , what with the sound of [the waters]1116-the waters and the rocking movement of [the ship]755-the ship , [I]0-i had either fallen asleep or was on the point of doing so when [a heavy man]1118-a heavy man sat down with [rather a clash close by]1119-rather a clash close by . The barrel shook as [he]1113-the man at the helm leaned [his]1113-the man at the helm shoulders against it , and [I]0-i was just about to jump up when [the man]2888-the man began to speak . It was [Silver]95-silver 's voice , and before [I]0-i had heard a dozen words , [I]0-i would not have shown [myself]0-i for all [the world]2855-the world , but lay there , trembling and listening , in the extreme of fear and curiosity , for from these dozen words [I]0-i understood that the lives of [all the honest men aboard]1122-all the honest men aboard depended upon [me]0-i alone .

" [We]3277-we 're [all forecastle hands]3283-all forecastle hands , [you]112-israel mean , "[95-silver] snapped [Silver]95-silver . " [We]3277-we can steer a course , but who 's to set one ? 12

Council of War

THERE was a great rush of feet across [the deck]1031-the deck . [I]0-i could hear [people]245-people tumbling up from [the cabin]950-the cabin and the forecastle , and slipping in an instant outside [my]0-i barrel , [I]0-i dived behind the fore - sail , made a double towards the stern , and came out upon [the open deck]1154-the open deck in time to join [Hunter]93-hunter and [Dr. Livesey]63-dr. livesey in the rush for the weather bow . There all hands were already congregated . A belt of fog had lifted almost simultaneously with the appearance of the moon . Away to [the south - west of [us]1156-us]1155-the south - west of us [we]1156-us saw [two low hills , about a couple of miles apart]1157-two low hills , about a couple of miles apart , and rising behind one of [them]1157-two low hills , about a couple of miles apart [a third and higher hill , whose peak was still buried in the fog]1158-a third and higher hill , whose peak was still buried in the fog . All three seemed sharp and conical in figure . So much [I]0-i saw , almost in a dream , for [I]0-i had not yet recovered from [my]0-i horrid fear of a minute or two before . And then [I]0-i heard the voice of [Captain Smollett]108-captain smollett issuing orders . [The HISPANIOLA]16-the hispaniola was laid a couple of points nearer the wind and now sailed a course that would just clear [the island on the east]1159-the island on the east . " Yes , [sir]2853-sir ; [Skeleton Island]32-skeleton island [they]3325-they calls [it]32-skeleton island .
